Lesson 2: Manipulating data frames

Lesson2.Rmd

Overview


Teaching: x mins
Exercises: 0 mins

Objectives:

  1. Import data into R
  2. Perform basic data manipulation using Tidyverse package
  3. Write readable R code


What is a data frame?

A data frame is the most common way of of storing data in R. Technically, it comprises of a list of equal-length vectors. Each element of the list can be thought of as a column and the length of each element of the list is the number of rows.

Most biological data are structured in the same manner as a data frame, i.e. a table that contain one or more column variables and an infinite number of rows listing the values of each variable. A data table can be saved as one of these file types:

  • generic text file: .txt
  • tab-separated values file: .tsv
  • comma-separated values file: .csv
  • excel file: .xls or .xlsx.

Importing data into R as data frame

Converting tabular data into an R data frame is a natural process. In this section, we will learn how to import data tables from your local computer into R.

Create a new RMarkdown file and save it on your local computer. Give the document an appropriate title in the metadata section and replace the default content of the document with a header ## Import data as in Figure 1.



We begin with retrieving a sample data from the cloud. This file contain a list of alternatively-spliced exons and its inclusion levels in two biological samples; Sfpq mutants and siblings. The data is saved in a tab-delimited file format (tsv). To download this file, create a new R chunk (click ) and type the following code into it:

download.file("https://bit.ly/36J7lx4", "splicing_data.tsv")


The function download.file will retrieve the content from the input hyperlink and save it to your current working directory under the filename splicing_data.tsv. To import this tsv into R, we will run the read.delim function and provide the name of the file as its input. Add the following code in the chunk above:

dat <- read.delim("splicing_data.tsv", stringsAsFactors = T)


and run the chunk by pressing the Run button (). Our data is successfully imported into R and assigned to the variable name dat.

Tip


In this example, the data file is found in the current working directory, hence providing the name of the file as input to read.delim is sufficient. However, to import files not found in the working directory, you would need to provide the full path to the file as input. To get this information, refer to this link for Windows user or this link for Mac user.


Previewing data frames

Once imported, R data frames can be previewed in many different ways.

The first 6 lines or 6 six rows of the data frame dat can be printed using the head or tail function. Create a sub-section in your RMarkdown document and insert these code into a new chunk:

head(dat)
tail(dat)

Upon running this chunk, you should get two tables that look like this:

Gene_id Gene_name Coord Strand Type Psi_control Psi_mutant
ENSDARG00000036650 cdadc1 1:45937851-45938028 - CE 0.89684 0.85626
ENSDARG00000036650 cdadc1 1:45936257-45936592 - AL 0.12117 0.13731
ENSDARG00000036650 cdadc1 1:45932974-45933558 - CE 0.91097 0.84387
ENSDARG00000036650 cdadc1 1:45930101-45930150 - CE 0.87502 0.83428
ENSDARG00000036650 cdadc1 1:45928441-45928610 - CE 0.90099 0.87379
ENSDARG00000036650 cdadc1 1:45928170-45928359 - CE 0.90005 0.84569
Gene_id Gene_name Coord Strand Type Psi_control Psi_mutant
159972 ENSDARG00000038941 ppp1r1c 9:44642239-44642299 + CE 0.94589 0.88444
159973 ENSDARG00000038941 ppp1r1c 9:44667281-44667315 + CE 0.93042 0.89334
159974 ENSDARG00000038941 ppp1r1c 9:44667526-44667592 + CE 0.94962 0.92238
159975 ENSDARG00000038941 ppp1r1c 9:44681722-44681925 + CE 0.37911 0.48088
159976 ENSDARG00000038941 ppp1r1c 9:44683845-44684345 + AL 0.48199 0.31010
159977 ENSDARG00000038941 ppp1r1c 9:44686736-44686894 + CE 0.92443 0.89328

The data frame contain 7 columns, and 159977 rows. The column names are shown at the very top of the table and each row represent one alternative exon. The description of the columns are as such:

Column name Description
Gene_id Given ID of the parental gene
Gene_name Gene name of the parental gene
Coord Genomic position of exon
Strand Whether exon is in the + or - strand
Type Type of alternative exon
CE: Casette exon
AF: Alternative first
AL:Alternative last
AD: Alternative donor
AA: Alternative acceptor
RI: Retained intron
Psi_control Percent spliced in index of exon in control
Psi_mutant Percent spliced in index of exon in mutant

The first 6 rows of the data frame can also be shown in a compact way using str function. Type the following code in a new code chunk and run it:

str(dat)

The above code should output:

##                Gene_id            Gene_name                      Coord       
##  ENSDARG00000099378:   260   zgc:174563:   260   1:10003490-10003530:     1  
##  ENSDARG00000099959:   168   smyhc1    :   168   1:10004609-10004693:     1  
##  ENSDARG00000067997:   150   myhz1.3   :   150   1:10007900-10008011:     1  
##  ENSDARG00000069692:   148   col7a1l   :   148   1:10036183-10036319:     1  
##  ENSDARG00000032630:   131   neb       :   131   1:10040088-10040216:     1  
##  ENSDARG00000093780:   126   (Other)   :153535   1:10043648-10043803:     1  
##  (Other)           :158994   NA's      :  5585   (Other)            :159971  
##  Strand    Type         Psi_control          Psi_mutant       
##  -:81807   AA:  5041   Min.   :0.0000881   Min.   :0.0001125  
##  +:78170   AD:  4230   1st Qu.:0.8958800   1st Qu.:0.8755300  
##            AF:  1920   Median :0.9593600   Median :0.9482000  
##            AL:   816   Mean   :0.8776923   Mean   :0.8705174  
##            CE:145191   3rd Qu.:0.9846200   3rd Qu.:0.9809100  
##            RI:  2779   Max.   :0.9999800   Max.   :0.9999700  
##

To summarize the contents of each column, we can run the summary function. Create a new code chunk and run the following code:

str(dat)

which should look like this:

##                Gene_id            Gene_name                      Coord       
##  ENSDARG00000099378:   260   zgc:174563:   260   1:10003490-10003530:     1

Practice on your own


The Markdown syntax contain various formattings that enhances the body of your document. Read this CheatSheet and attempt the following tasks in a new RMarkdown document.

  1. Create an ordered list containing 3 of your favorite food
  2. Bold the #1 fav from the above list
  3. Insert an image of your #1 fav food. Can be from a local image on your computer or from a hyperlink.

Render the created RMarkdown as HTML and compare your output with mine (found here).
